controller

Class Interpreter

  • java.lang.Object
    • controller.Interpreter
  • Deprecated.

    public class Interpreter
extends Object
    This is the controller class. It is a static class. It translates Prolog-like declaration into objects for the program.
    Author:
    Alexandre Camus

    • Method Detail

      • isConstant

        public static boolean isConstant(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches the constant pattern. A constant must start with a number or a non-capital letter. It is a alpha-numeric word and can have the symbol _.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToConstant().

        Parameters:
        string - that is the constant.
        Returns:
        true if the string correspond to the constant pattern.

      • stringToConstant

        public static Constant stringToConstant(String string)
                                 throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Constant object. The input string should be a constant.
        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Constant object.
        Returns:
        the Constant object representing the constant string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a constant according to the method isConstant().
        See Also:
        Constant, isConstant(String)

      • isVariable

        public static boolean isVariable(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches the variable pattern. A variable must start a capital letter. It is a alpha-numeric word and can have the symbol _.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToVariable().

        Parameters:
        string - that is the variable.
        Returns:
        true if the string correspond to the variable pattern.

      • stringToVariable

        public static Variable stringToVariable(String string,
                        HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                                 throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Variable object. The input string should be a variable.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Variable object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the Variable object representing the variable string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a variable according to the method isVariable().
        See Also:
        Variable, isVariable(String)

      • isSimpleSentence

        public static boolean isSimpleSentence(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches the simple sentence pattern. It is a predicate or an event. This string has the form of: 'constant(parameters)' where 'parameters' are variables or constants separate by a comma. Constants and variables are checks thanks to their own methods: isConstant() and isVariable().

        See a Prolog documentation for more information about Prolog predicate. This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToSimpleSentence().

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToSimpleSentence().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether it is a simple sentence or not.
        Returns:
        true if it matches the general form of a simple sentence, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        Prolog documentation

      • stringToSimpleSentence

        public static SimpleSentence stringToSimpleSentence(String string,
                                    HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                                             throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a SimpleSentence object. The input string should be a simple sentence. It uses the methods stringToAnd(), stringToNegation() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the whole clause.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the SimpleSentence object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the SimpleSentence object representing the simple sentence string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a simple sentence according to the method isSimpleSentence.
        See Also:
        SimpleSentence, isSimpleSentence(String)

      • isDPostDeclaration

        public static boolean isDPostDeclaration(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches the DPost declaration pattern. A DPost declaration is a simple sentence which name is 'initiates' or 'terminates'. It has two parameters: an event which is a simple sentence and a fluent which is also a simple sentence.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToDPost().

        See a LPS documentation for more details on DPost declaration.

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it matches the DPost declaration syntax.
        Returns:
        true if the string is a DPost declaration, otherwise false.

      • stringToDPost

        public static DPostDeclaration stringToDPost(String string,
                             HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                                      throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a DPostDeclaration object. The input string should be a DPost declaration. It creates an Initiator or a Terminator object depending on the input.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the DPostDeclaration object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the DPostDeclaration object representing the simple sentence string input. It will be either a Initiator object or an Terminator object.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a DPostDeclaration according to the method isDPostDeclaration().
        See Also:
        SimpleSentence, isSimpleSentence(String)

      • isAnd

        public static boolean isAnd(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches an and-clause. An and-clause is a n-ary operator. Each operand is separated by a '&'. An operand can be a simple sentence or a negative clause.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToAnd().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it is an and-clause.
        Returns:
        true if the string is an and-clause, otherwise false.

      • isNegation

        public static boolean isNegation(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches an negative clause. A negative clause is a unary operator. Its only operand is a simple sentence or an and-clause.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToNegation().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it is a negative clause.
        Returns:
        true if the string is a negative clause, otherwise false.

      • isEquality

        public static boolean isEquality(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches an equality clause. An equality clause is a binary operator. Its both operands are a variable and a unifiable sentence.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToEquality().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it is an equality clause.
        Returns:
        true if the string is an equality clause, otherwise false.

      • stringToAnd

        public static And stringToAnd(String string,
              HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                       throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a And object. The input string should be an and-clause. It uses the methods stringToAnd(), stringToNegation() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the whole clause.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the And object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the And object representing the and-clause string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to an and-clause according to the method isAnd().
        See Also:
        And, isAnd(String)

      • stringToNegation

        public static Not stringToNegation(String string,
                   HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                            throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Not object. The input string should be a negative clause. It uses the methods stringToAnd(), stringToNegation() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the whole clause.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Not object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the Not object representing the negative clause string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a negative clause according to the method isNot().
        See Also:
        Not, isNegation(String)

      • stringToEquality

        public static Equal stringToEquality(String string,
                     HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                              throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Equal object. The input string should be an equality clause. It uses the methods stringToConstant(), stringToVariable() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the whole clause.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Equal object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the Equal object representing the equality clause string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to an equality clause according to the method isEquality().
        See Also:
        Equal, isEquality(String)

      • stringToClause

        public static Clause stringToClause(String string,
                    HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                             throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Clause object. The input string should be a clause. It uses the methods stringToAnd(), stringToNegation() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the whole clause.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Clause object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the Clause object representing the clause string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a clause according to the method isNot(), isAnd() or isSimpleSentence().
        See Also:
        Clause, isNegation(String), isAnd(String), isSimpleSentence(String)

      • isReactiveRule

        public static boolean isReactiveRule(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches a reactive rule. A reactive rule is a binary imply. Its first operand is a clause. Its second operand is a simple sentence.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToReactiveRule().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it is a reactive rule.
        Returns:
        true if the string is a reactive rule, otherwise false.

      • stringToReactiveRule

        public static ReactiveRule stringToReactiveRule(String string,
                                HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                                         throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a ReactiveRule object. The input string should be a reactive rule. It uses the methods stringToClause() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the reactive rule.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the ReactiveRule object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the ReactiveRule object representing the reactive rule string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a reactive rule according to the method isReactiveRule()
        See Also:
        ReactiveRule, isReactiveRule(String)

      • isRule

        public static boolean isRule(String string)
        Deprecated. 
        Checks whether the input string matches a rule. A rule is a binary backward imply. Its first operand is a simple sentence. Its second operand is a clause.

        This method is used to throw exceptions in stringToRule().

        Parameters:
        string - to be checked whether or not it is a rule.
        Returns:
        true if the string is a rule, otherwise false.

      • stringToRule

        public static Rule stringToRule(String string,
                HashMap<String,Variable> variables)
                         throws RemoteException
        Deprecated. 
        Converts the input string into a Rule object. The input string should be a rule. It uses the methods stringToClause() and stringToSimpleSentence() recursively to create the rule.

        The variable variables is used to pass the variables created to the whole clause to avoid to create two different variables for the same one. Initialize it with null or a brand new HashMap.

        Parameters:
        string - to be converted into the Rule object.
        variables - the variables already created to be reused if necessary and it will be updated with the new created variables.
        Returns:
        the Rule object representing the reactive rule string input.
        Throws:
        RemoteException - if the input does not correspond to a reactive rule according to the method isRule()
        See Also:
        Rule, isRule(String)
